Fragmento en griego: τοῦ δὲ λόγου τοῦδ ἐόντος ἀεὶ ἀξύνετοι γίνονται ἄνθρωποι καὶ πρόσθεν ἢ ἀκοῦσαι καὶ ἀκούσαντες τὸ πρῶτον· γινομένων γὰρ πάντων κατὰ τὸν λόγον τόνδε ἀπείροισιν ἐοίκασι πειρώμενοι καὶ ἐπέων καὶ ἔργων τοιούτων ὁκοίων ἐγὼ διηγεῦμαι κατὰ φύσιν διαιρέων ἕκαστον καὶ φράζων ὅκως ἔχει· τοὺς δὲ ἄλλους ἀνθρώπους λανθάνει ὁκόσα ἐγερθέντες ποιοῦσιν ὅκωσπερ ὁκόσα εὕδοντες ἐπιλανθάνονται
Traducción: Aunque este Logos existe eternamente, los hombres son incapaces de comprenderlo tanto antes de oírlo como una vez que lo han oído. Pues aunque todo sucede conforme a este Logos, parecen inexpertos al probar palabras y hechos como los que yo expongo al distinguir cada cosa según su naturaleza y mostrar cómo es. Pero los demás hombres ignoran lo que hacen despiertos, como olvidan lo que hacen dormidos.
Translation: Though this Word is true evermore, yet men are as unable to understand it when they hear it for the first time as before they have heard it at all. For, though all things come to pass in accordance with this Word, men seem as if they had no experience of them, when they make trial of words and deeds such as I set forth, dividing each thing according to its kind and showing how it is what it is. But other men know not what they are doing when awake, even as they forget what they do in sleep.
Nota: Two different sources say that this comes from the beginning of Heraclitus' book. For that reason, DK rightly put it as B1. Most of the other fragments are short oral sayings, easy to remember. However, this fragment has a very literary style. This fragment and B48 lead me to conclude that Heraclitus' book was a written and not an oral document. Aristotle points to the ambiguity in the first line. He says that ἀεὶ (forever) ambiguously could modify either ἐόντος (is) orἀξύνετοι (not comprehending) --Rhetoric 3.1407b11. Some think this was intentional, while others think that it is just unclear. Some translations try to capture the ambiguity: "Of this account which holds forever men prove uncomprehending" (Barnes), where "forever" could modify either how the λόγος (account) holds or how long men prove uncomprehending of it.

Fragmento en griego: τοῦ λόγου δ' ἐόντος ξυνοῦ ζώουσιν οἱ πολλοὶ ὡς ἰδίαν ἔχοντες φρόνησιν
Traducción: Aunque el Logos es común, la mayoría vive como si tuviera una inteligencia privada.
Translation: Thoughthe logosis common, the many live as if they had a wisdom of their own.
Nota: Burnet translates λόγος as 'Word,' but I have chosen to leave it as logos in this fragment.

Fragmento en griego: [περὶ μεγέθους ἡλίου] εὖρος ποδὸς ἀνθρωπείου
Traducción: [Sobre el tamaño del sol:] el ancho de un pie humano.
Translation: [Concerning the size of the sun: it is] the width of a human foot
Nota: Diogenes Laertius (IX, 7) says that Heraclitus said, "The sun is the size that it appears." (Robinson 78)

Fragmento en griego: Si felicitas esset in delectationibus corporis, boves felices diceremus, cum inveniant orobum ad comedendum.
Traducción: Si la felicidad consistiera en los placeres del cuerpo, llamaríamos felices a los bueyes cuando encuentran arveja amarga para comer.
Translation: If happiness consisted in the pleasures of the body, we should call oxen happy whenever they come across bitter vetch to eat.
Nota: This fragment has been preserved in Latin. It does not bear any relation to any of the other fragments we do possess. It sounds more like a Platonic or Aristotelian contrast between the pleasures of the body and the pleasures of the rational soul. For these reasons, most scholars treat this fragment with caution.

Fragmento en griego: καθαίρονται δ' ἄλλως αἵματι μιαινόμενοι, ὁκοῖον εἴ τις εἰς πηλὸν ἐμβὰς πηλῷ ἀπονίζοιτο· μαίνεσθαι δ' ἂν δοκέοι εἴ τις μιν ἀνθρώπων ἐπιθράσαιτο οὕτω ποιέοντα. καὶ τοῖς ἀγάλμασι δὲ τουτέοισιν εὔχονται, ὁκοῖον εἴ τις τοῖς δόμοισι λεσχηνεύοιτο, οὔ τι γινώσκων θεοὺς οὐδ' ἥρωας οἵτινές εἰσι
Traducción: Se purifican manchándose con sangre, como si alguien que se hubiera hundido en el lodo intentara lavarse con lodo. Parecería loco a cualquiera que lo viera actuar así. Y rezan ante estas imágenes, como si alguien conversara con las paredes de una casa, sin conocer en absoluto quiénes son los dioses y los héroes.

Fragmento en griego: ὁ ἥλιος... καθάπερ ὁ Ἡράκλειτός φησι, νέος ἐφ' ἡμέρῃ ἐστίν
Traducción: El sol... como dice Heráclito, es nuevo cada día.
Translation: The sun... as Heraclitus says, is new every day.
Nota: This fragments comes from Aristotle. Here is his full text: "The sun is not only, as Heraclitus says, new each day but forever continuously new" (Meteorology 2.2.355a13).

Fragmento en griego: εἰ πάντα τὰ ὄντα καπνὸς γένοιτο, ῥῖνες ἂν διαγνοῖεν.
Traducción: Si todas las cosas existentes se convirtieran en humo, las narices las distinguirían.
Translation: If all things were turned to smoke, the nostrils would distinguish them.
Nota: This fragment is quoted in Aristotle. Some commentators believe that Aristotle added the phraseτὰ ὄντα (existing things) as a gloss over Heraclitus's use of πάντα (all things). Robinson argues that if Heraclitus had spoken about 'reality' asτὰ ὄντα, he would have used ἐόντα (Ionic form ofὄντα) as he uses elsewhere. I find this argument convincing. It still could be that Aristotle is loosely paraphrasing a thought of Heraclitus.

Fragmento en griego: τὸ ἀντίξουν συμφέρον καὶ ἐκ τῶν διαφερόντων καλλίστην ἁρμονίαν καὶ πάντα κατ' ἔριν γίνεσθαι
Traducción: Lo opuesto concuerda, y de las diferencias surge la más bella armonía, y todo ocurre según discordia.
Translation: What opposes unites, and the finest attunement stems from things bearing in opposite directions, and all things come about by strife.
Nota: This fragment is divided into three phrases. Most editors agree that Aristotle is quoting or paraphrasing from memory. The last phrase, καὶ πάντα κατ' ἔριν γίνεσθαι (all things come about by strife), is most likely a paraphrase of B80.The middle phrase,ἐκ τῶν διαφερόντων καλλίστην ἁρμονίαν (the finest attunement stems from things bearing in opposite directions), Marcovich argues, is most likely a paraphrase of B51.The first phrase is not attested for elsewhere. Robinson noticed the Ionic word ἀντίξουν (opposes) and argued from this that the first phrase contains Heraclitus's actual words.

Fragmento en griego: ἑτέρα γὰρ ἵππου ἡδονὴ καὶ κυνὸς καὶ ἀνθρώπου, ὄνους σύρματ' ἂν ἑλέσθαι μᾶλλον ἢ χρυσόν· ἥδιον γὰρ χρυσοῦ τροφὴ ὄνοις
Traducción: El placer es distinto para un caballo, un perro y un hombre; los asnos preferirían paja al oro; pues para los asnos el alimento es más dulce que el oro.
Translation: For a horse, a dog and a human being have different pleasures;asses prefer straw to gold, since asses find food sweeter than gold.
Nota: Most editors recognize the phrase ὄνους σύρματ' ἂν ἑλέσθαι μᾶλλον ἢ χρυσόν (asses prefer straw to gold) as Heraclitus', and the rest as comments by Aristotle. The translation of Aristotle's comments comes from Terrance Irwin's translation of Aristotle's Nicomachean Ethics.

Fragmento en griego: συλλάψιες· ὅλα καὶ οὐχ ὅλα, συμφερόμενον διαφερόμενον, συνᾷδον διᾷδον καὶ ἐκ πάντων ἓν καὶ ἐξ ἑνὸς πάντα
Traducción: Conjunciones: cosas enteras y no enteras, convergente divergente, consonante disonante, y de todas las cosas una y de una todas las cosas.
Translation: Graspings: things whole and not whole, what is drawn together and what is drawn asunder, the harmonious and the discordant. The one is made up of all things, and all things issue from the one.
Nota: Many editors translate συλλάψιεςas 'couples', 'connections', 'assemblages', &c. Kahn argues that the only sense of the word attested before Aristotle is 'things seized by force, grasped, or apprehended.'

Fragmento en griego: πᾶν γὰρ ἑρπετὸν πληγῇ νέμεται
Traducción: Toda bestia es llevada al pasto a golpes.
Translation: Every beast is driven to pasture with a blow.
Nota: This fragment may be just a paraphrase. Some have suggested that Heraclitus may have used the noun nomo/s (pasture) instead of the verb given here ne/metai (to be driven to pasture). If so, then this fragment would be a play on words between no/mos (law) and nomo/s (pasture): either natural law that drives all things (or all things are naturally driven to law), just as animals are driven to a pasture.

Fragmento en griego: ποταμοῖσι τοῖσιν αὐτοῖσιν ἐμβαίνουσιν ἕτερα καὶ ἕτερα ὕδατα ἐπιρρεῖ
Traducción: Sobre quienes entran en los mismos ríos, fluyen aguas siempre diferentes.
Translation: On those who enter the same rivers, ever different waters flow.
Nota: Three versions of this fragment exist: B12|49a (see below)|B91 Because of this fact, there is much debate on which version is authentic (if any) and what it means. B49a: "We step and do not step in to the same rivers; we are and are not." B12 is a fragment about the unity/diversity inherit in reality. Reality is changing and in flux (like the the different waters), yet it is all stable and unified (like a river). B49a assigns change and stability to the one stepping into the river as well as the river. B91 focuses just on the diversity and not on the unity. I think that B49a above is authentic (at least the first half). B12 also seems authentic, giving the reason for B49a: "different and different waters flow" upon those who step into a river.

Fragmento en griego: ὕες βορβόρῳ ἥδονται μᾶλλον ἢ καθαρῷ ὕδατι
Traducción: Los cerdos se deleitan en el cieno más que en agua limpia.
Translation: Pigs delight in the mire more than in clean water.
Nota: Burnet takes only "to delight in the mire" as authentic.

Fragmento en griego: τὰ γὰρ νομιζόμενα κατ' ἀνθρώπους μυστήρια ἀνιερωστὶ μυενται
Traducción: Los misterios que los hombres practican son misterios profanos.
Translation: The mysteries practiced among men are unholy mysteries

Fragmento en griego: εἰ μὴ γὰρ Διονύσῳ πομπὴν ἐποιοῦντο καὶ ὕμνεον ᾆσμα αἰδοίοισιν, ἀναιδέστατα εἴργαστ' ἄν· ὡυτὸς δὲ Ἀίδης καὶ Διόνυσος, ὅτεῳ μαίνονται καὶ ληναΐζουσιν
Traducción: Pues si no hicieran procesión a Dioniso y cantaran el himno vergonzoso a los genitales, cometerían los actos más desvergonzados. Pero Hades es lo mismo que Dioniso, en cuyo honor enloquecen y deliran.
Translation: For if it were not to Dionysus that they made a procession and sang the shameful phallic hymn, they would be acting most shamelessly. But Hades is the same as Dionysus in whose honor they go mad and rave.

Fragmento en griego: τὸ μὴ δῦνόν ποτε πῶς ἄν τις λάθοι;
Traducción: ¿Cómo podría alguien esconderse de lo que nunca se pone?
Translation: How can one hide from that which never sets?

Fragmento en griego: οὐ γὰρ φρονέουσι τοιαῦτα πολλοί, ὁκοίσοι ἐγκυρεῦσιν, οὐδὲ μαθόντες γινώσκουσιν, ἑωυτοῖσι δὲ δοκέουσι
Traducción: La mayoría no entiende tales cosas cuando las encuentran, ni las reconocen aunque se las enseñen, aunque creen que sí.
Translation: The many do not take heed of such things as those they meet with, nor do they recognize them when they are taught, though they think they do
Nota: I consistenly translate words with γιγν -in them as 'to recognize.' (See 'Cognition' under categories.)

Fragmento en griego: ἐὰν μὴ ἔλπηται ἀνέλπιστον οὐκ ἐξευρήσει, ἀνεξερεύνητον ἐὸν καὶ ἄπορον
Traducción: Si no esperas lo inesperado, no lo hallarás, pues es difícil de descubrir e inaccesible.
Translation: If you do not expect the unexpected, you will not find it; for it is hard to be sought out and difficult.

Fragmento en griego: ἀκοῦσαι οὐκ ἐπιστάμενοι οὐδ' εἰπεῖν
Traducción: No sabiendo escuchar, tampoco [saben] hablar.
Translation: Knowing not how to listen, they do not [know]how to speak
Nota: Burnet translates this fragment as this: "Knowing not how to listen nor how to speak." I think Heraclitus was saying that that not knowing how to speak is a result of not knowing how to listen.

Fragmento en griego: γενόμενοι ζώειν ἐθέλουσι μόρους τ' ἔχειν, μᾶλλον δὲ ἀναπαύεσθαι, καὶ παῖδας καταλείπουσι μόρους γενέσθαι
Traducción: Al nacer, desean vivir y tener destinos, o más bien descansar, y dejan hijos para que también tengan sus destinos.
Translation: When they are born, they wish to live and to meet with their dooms -- or rather to rest -- and they leave children behind them to meet with their dooms in turn.
Nota: It is difficult to determine exactly which parts of the fragment are authentic quotations of Heraclitus. Clement, the source for this fragment, adds "-- or rather to rest --" but I take the rest as a quotation.

Fragmento en griego: θάνατός ἐστιν ὁκόσα ἐγερθέντες ὁρέομεν, ὁκόσα δὲ εὕδοντες ὕπνος
Traducción: La muerte es lo que vemos despiertos, lo que vemos dormidos es sueño.
Translation: All the things we see when awake are death, even as all we see in slumber are sleep.

Fragmento en griego: χρυσὸν γὰρ οἱ διζήμενοι γῆν πολλὴν ὀρύσσουσι καὶ εὑρίσκουσιν ὀλίγον
Traducción: Los que buscan oro excavan mucha tierra y encuentran poco.
Translation: Those who seek for gold dig up much earth and find a little.
Nota: A different form of διζήμενοι (seeking) is also used in B101.

Fragmento en griego: Δίκης ὄνομα οὐκ ἂν ᾔδεσαν, εἰ ταῦτα μὴ ἦν
Traducción: No conocerían el nombre de Justicia si estas cosas no existieran.
Translation: They would not have known the name of justice if these things were not.
Nota: An emendation has been made to ᾔδεσαν (would know) from the manuscript ἔδησαν (would have bound). It is unclear what ταῦτα (these things) refers to and who/what is the subject of ᾔδεσαν (would know).

Fragmento en griego: ἀρηϊφάτους θεοὶ τιμῶσι καὶ ἄνθρωποι
Traducción: Dioses y hombres honran a los muertos en batalla.
Translation: Gods and men honor those who are slain by Ares.
Nota: The term ἀρηϊφάτους is a compound word meaning those-slain-by-Ares. Burnet gives a gloss of 'slain in battle,' and this is no doubt Heraclitus' intention.

Fragmento en griego: μόροι γὰρ μέζονες μέζονας μοίρας λαγχάνουσι
Traducción: Muertes mayores obtienen mayores porciones.
Translation: Greater deaths win greater portions.
Nota: Heraclitus uses μόροι (death) and μοίρας (portions) exploiting their common etymology. I am inclined to believe that Heraclitus thinks language teaches this truth and language alone gives sufficient evidence for the claim.

Fragmento en griego: ἄνθρωπος ἐν εὐφρόνῃ φάος ἅπτεται ἑαυτῷ [ἀποθανὼν] ἀποσβεσθεὶς ὄψεις, ζῶν δὲ ἅπτεται τεθνεῶτος εὔδων, [ἀποσβεσθεὶς ὄψεις], ἐγρηγορὼς ἅπτεται εὕδοντος
Traducción: El hombre enciende una luz para sí mismo en la noche, cuando ha muerto pero está vivo. El durmiente, cuya visión se ha apagado, se ilumina desde el muerto; el despierto se ilumina desde el dormido.
Translation: Man kindles a light for himself in the night-time, when he has died but is alive. The sleeper, whose vision has been put out, lights up from the dead; he that is awake lights up from the sleeping.
Nota: Most editors believe that Clement (the source for this fragment) added the words in brackets to Heraclitus' own, thus giving his own interpretation. These words are not included in Burnet's translation.

Fragmento en griego: ἀνθρώπους μένει ἀποθανόντας ἄσσα οὐκ ἔλπονται οὐδὲ δοκέουσιν
Traducción: Les aguarda a los hombres al morir cosas que ni esperan ni imaginan.
Translation: There awaits men when they die such things as they look not for nor dream of.

Fragmento en griego: δοκέοντα γὰρ ὁ δοκιμώτατος γινώσκει, φυλάσσει· [καὶ μέντοι καὶ] Δίκη καταλήψεται ψευδῶν τέκτονας καὶ μάρτυρας
Traducción: El más estimado entre ellos conoce —se aferra a— apariencias. La Justicia atrapará a los artífices de mentiras y a los falsos testigos.
Translation: The most esteemed of them knows-- holds fast to --fancies.Justice shall overtake the artificers of lies and the false witnesses.
Nota: This fragment really seems to be two fragments that Clement has linked together. With Robinson, I do not think that these two fragments should be put together. The phrase in brackets seems to have been added by Clement to connect these two fragments; it has been left out of the translation.

Fragmento en griego: αἱρεῦνται γὰρ ἒν ἀντὶ ἀπάντων οἱ ἄριστοι, κλέος ἀέναον θνητῶν· οἱ δὲ πολλοὶ κεκόρηνται ὄκωσπερ κτήνεα
Traducción: Pues los mejores eligen una cosa sobre todas: gloria inmortal entre mortales, mientras la mayoría se sacia como el ganado.
Translation: For even the best of them choose one thing above all others, immortal glory among mortals, while most of them are glutted like beasts.

Fragmento en griego: κόσμον τόνδε, τὸν αὐτὸν ἁπάντων, οὔτε τις θεῶν οὐτε ἀνθρώπων ἐποίησεν, ἀλλ' ἦν ἀεὶ καὶ ἔστιν καὶ ἔσται πῦρ ἀείζωον, ἁπτόμενον μέτρα καὶ ἀποσβεννύμενον μέτρα
Traducción: Este mundo, el mismo para todos, no lo hizo ningún dios ni hombre, sino que siempre fue, es y será fuego siempre vivo, que se enciende con medida y se apaga con medida.
Translation: This world, which is the same for all, no one of gods or men has made. But it always was, is, and will be: an ever-living Fire, with measures of it kindling, and measures going out.
Nota: Clement quotes B30 and B31 in the same context. His complete text reads: "Now that [Heraclitus] recognized that the world which is uniquely characterized by the totality of substance is eternal, is evident when he says:The world, the same for all, neither any god nor any man made; but it was always and is and will be, fire ever-living, kindling in measures and being extinguished in measures. [B30] And that he believed it to be generated and destructible is indicated by the following words: Turnings of fire: first, sea; of sea, half is earth, half lightning flash. [B31a] -- He says in effect that, by reason and good which rule everything, fire is turned by way of air into moisture, the seed, as it were, of creation, which he calls sea; and from this, again, come earth and heaven and what they contain. He shows clearly in the following words that they are restored again and become fire: Sea is dissolved and measured into the same proportion that existed at first. [B31b] And the same holds for the other elements" (Barnes 122).

Fragmento en griego: θάλασσα διαχέεται καὶ μετρέεται εἰς τὸν αὐτὸν λόγον ὁκοῖος πρόσθεν ἦν ἢ γενέσθαι γῆ
Traducción: El mar se derrama y se mide según la misma proporción que existía antes.
Translation: The transformations of Fire: first, sea; and of the sea half is earth, half whirlwind...
Nota: See text notes on B30.

Fragmento en griego: ἕν τὸ σοφὸν μοῦνον λέγεσθαι οὐκ ἐθέλει καὶ ἐθέλει Ζηνὸς ὄνομα
Traducción: Lo único sabio no quiere y quiere ser llamado con el nombre de Zeus.
Translation: The wise is one only. It is unwilling and willing to be called by the name of Zeus.
Nota: Heraclitus uses the obscure word Ζηνὸς here for Zeus. It is related to the word ζάω (to live). Whether or not Heraclitus intended this as a pun is a matter of conjecture.

Fragmento en griego: νόμος καὶ βουλῇ πείθεσθαι ἑνός
Traducción: Es ley también obedecer el consejo de uno.
Translation: And it is law, too, to obey the counsel of one.

Fragmento en griego: ἀξύνετοι ἀκούσαντες κωφοῖσιν ἐοίκασι· φάτις αὐτοῖσιν μαρτυρεῖ παρεόντας ἀπεῖναι
Traducción: Los que oyen sin comprender se asemejan a sordos; el dicho atestigua que estando presentes, están ausentes.
Translation: Hearing they do not understand,
Nota: I have adjusted the translation to sharply show the distinction between hearing and understanding. Also, I have cited the saying as a quotation.

Fragmento en griego: χρὴ εὖ μάλα πολλῶν ἵστορας φιλοσόφους ἄνδρας εἶναι
Traducción: Los hombres que aman la sabiduría deben ser investigadores de muchas cosas.
Translation: Men that love wisdom must be inquirers into very many things indeed.
Nota: I consider Heraclitus' use ofἵστορας (inquirers [into]) to be a technical term, referring to the scientific methods of his predecessors. Burnet translates the word as "acquainted [with]." See Inquiry under categories.

Fragmento en griego: ψυχῇσιν θάνατος ὕδωρ γενέσθαι, ὕδατι δὲ θάνατος γῆν γενέσθαι, ἐκ γῆς δὲ ὕδωρ γίνεται, ἐξ ὕδατος δὲ ψυχή
Traducción: Para las almas es muerte convertirse en agua, y para el agua muerte convertirse en tierra. Pero del agua viene la tierra, y del agua, el alma.
Translation: For it is death to souls to become water, and death to water to become earth. But water comes from earth; and from water, soul.

Fragmento en griego: Sues caeno cohortales aves pulvere vel cinere lavari
Traducción: Los cerdos se lavan en el barro, y las aves de corral en polvo.
Translation: Swine wash in the mire, and barnyard fowls in dust.
Nota: This fragment has been preserved for us in Latin. Most scholars treat it as a paraphrase and not a (translation of a) direct quote. The thought definitely seems Heraclitean, and I see no reason to reject it.

Fragmento en griego: δοκεῖ [Θαλῆς] δὲ κατά τινας πρῶτος ἀστρολογῆσαι... μαρτυρεῖ δ' αὐτῷ καὶ Ἡράκλειτος καὶ Δημόκριτος
Traducción: [Tales] parece haber sido el primer astrónomo... hecho que atestiguan Heráclito y Demócrito.
Translation: [Thales], according to some, seems to have been the first student of astronomy... a fact that both Heraclitus and Democritus bear witness to.
Nota: This fragment comes from Diogenes Laertius, in his section on Thales. This fragment has the only mention of Thales in Heraclitus' work (cf. B105 regarding Homer). See the Perseus Encyclopedia entry for this figure: Thales

Fragmento en griego: ἐν Πριήνῃ Βίας ἐγένετο ὁ Τευτάμεω, οὗ πλείων λόγος ἢ τῶν ἄλλων
Traducción: En Priene vivió Bias, hijo de Teutamas, quien vale más que los demás.
Translation: In Priene lived Bias, son of Teutamas, who is of more account than the rest.
Nota: See Bias of Priene' sentry in the Perseus Encyclopedia (he's Bias 1).

Fragmento en griego: πολυμαθίη νόον οὐ διδάσκει· Ἡσίοδον γὰρ ἂν ἐδίδαξε καὶ Πυθαγόρην, αὖτίς τε Ξενοφάνεά τε καὶ Ἑκαταῖον
Traducción: La erudición de muchas cosas no enseña entendimiento; de lo contrario, habría enseñado a Hesíodo, Pitágoras, y también a Jenófanes y Hecateo.
Translation: The learning of many things does not teach understanding; otherwise, it would have taught Hesiod and Pythagoras, and again Xenophanes and Hecataeus.
Nota: See the Perseus Encyclopedia entries for these figures: Hesiod Pythagoras (he's Pythagoras 5) Hecataeus

Fragmento en griego: ἓν τὸ σοφόν, ἐπίστασθαι γνώμην, ὁτέη ἐκυβέρνησε πάντα διὰ πάντων
Traducción: Una cosa es lo sabio: conocer la inteligencia que gobierna todas las cosas a través de todas.
Translation: Wisdom is one thing. It is to know the thought by which all things are steered through all things.
Nota: The text for the this fragment has been corrupted. The manuscripts have ὅτεη κυβερνῆσαι. I have provided the emendation made by DK: ὅτεη ἐκυβέρνησε. Robinson accepts this emendation as well, although noting a hesitation based on the feminine form of ὅστις (ὅτεη), which occurs nowhere in Greek literature. Kahn finds the ὅτεη impossible, and emends the whole phrase to this: ὅκη κυβερνᾶται.

Fragmento en griego: τόν τε Ὅμηρον ἔφασκεν ἄξιον ἐκ τῶν ἀγώνων ἐκβάλλεσθαι καὶ ῥαπίζεσθαι, καὶ Ἀρχίλοχον ὁμοίως
Traducción: Homero merece ser expulsado de los certámenes y apaleado, y también Arquíloco.
Translation: Homer deserves to be taken out of the games and beaten with a stick, and Archilochus too.
Nota: See the entries the Perseus Encyclopedia entries for these figures: Archilochus Homer

Fragmento en griego: ὕβριν χρὴ σβεννύναι μᾶλλον ἢ πυρκαῖήν
Traducción: La insolencia debe apagarse más que un incendio.
Translation: Wantonness needs putting out, even more than a house on fire.

Fragmento en griego: μάχεσθαι χρὴ τὸν δῆμον ὑπὲρ τοῦ νόμου ὅκωσπερ τείχεος
Traducción: El pueblo debe luchar por su ley como por sus murallas.
Translation: The people must fight for its law as for its walls.

Fragmento en griego: ψυχῆς πείρατα ἰὼν οὐκ ἂν ἐξεύροιο πᾶσαν ἐπιπορευόμενος ὁδόν· οὕτω βαθὺν λόγον ἔχει
Traducción: Límites del alma no hallarías aunque recorrieras todo camino: tan profunda medida tiene.
Translation: Traveling on every path
Nota: λόγος is the word used for measure. Presumably, it is not being used in Heraclitus' technical sense. (See λόγος under categories.)

Fragmento en griego: τήν τε οἴησιν ἱερὰν νόσον ἔλεγε καὶ τὴν ὅρασιν ψεύδεσθαι
Traducción: Decía que la presunción es enfermedad sagrada y que la vista engaña.
Translation: Heraclitus said that thinking is a sacred disease and that sight is deceptive.
Nota: If this fragment is genuine at all, it is a paraphrase made by Diogenes Laertius and not a direct quote. It does seem to fit something that Heraclitus may have said. Marcovich points out that the word οἴησιν does not occur anywhere in Greek literature until the fourth century B.C.E., and thus it is highly unlikely that Heraclitus used this word.

Fragmento en griego: μὴ εἰκῆ περὶ τῶν μεγίστων συμβαλλώμεθα
Traducción: No conjeturemos a la ligera sobre las cosas más importantes.
Translation: Let us not conjecture randomly about the most important things.

Fragmento en griego: βιός τῷ τόξῳ ὄνομα βίος ἔργον δὲ θάνατος
Traducción: Arco: el nombre del arco es vida, pero su obra es muerte.
Translation: Bow: the bow's name is life, though its work is death.
Nota: These words for bow (βιός) and life (βίος) were pronounced differently because of accentuation. However, when written down, they looked identical (ΒΙΟΣ / ΒΙΟΣ). Heraclitus plays on this written ambiguity in this fragment. This fragment shows that Heraclitus did not compose his book as a set of spoken statements; his book is clearly a written one. This fragment only has its force if it were written down.

Fragmento en griego: εἷς ἐμοὶ μύριοι, ἐὰν ἄριστος ᾖ
Traducción: Uno solo vale diez mil para mí, si es el mejor.
Translation: One is ten thousand to me, if he be the best.
Nota: Many recent scholars reject ἐμοὶ (to me).

Fragmento en griego: οὐκ ἐμοῦ, ἀλλὰ τοῦ λόγου ἀκούσαντας ὁμολογεῖν σοφόν ἐστιν ἓν πάντα εἶναι
Traducción: Habiendo escuchado, no a mí, sino al Logos, es sabio convenir en que todas las cosas son una.

Fragmento en griego: οὐ ξυνιᾶσιν ὅκως διαφερόμενον ἑωυτῷ ὁμολογέει· παλίντροπος ἁρμονίη ὅκωσπερ τόξου καὶ λύρης
Traducción: No comprenden cómo lo que difiere está de acuerdo consigo mismo: armonía en tensión opuesta, como en el arco y la lira.

Fragmento en griego: αἰὼν παῖς ἐστι παίζων, πεττεύων· παιδὸς ἡ βασιληίη
Traducción: El tiempo es un niño que juega, moviendo piezas; reinado de un niño.

Fragmento en griego: πόλεμος πάντων μὲν πατήρ ἐστι, πάντων δὲ βασιλεύς, καὶ τοὺς μὲν θεοὺς ἔδειξε τοὺς δὲ ἀνθρώπους, τοὺς μὲν δούλους ἐποίησε τοὺς δὲ ἐλευθέρους
Traducción: La guerra es padre de todos, rey de todos; a unos los muestra como dioses, a otros como hombres; a unos los hace esclavos, a otros libres.

Fragmento en griego: ἁρμονίη ἀφανὴς φανερῆς κρείττων
Traducción: La armonía oculta es más poderosa que la visible.

Fragmento en griego: ὅσων ὄψις ἀκοὴ μάθησις, ταῦτα ἐγὼ προτιμέω
Traducción: Todo lo que puede ser visto, oído y aprendido: eso es lo que yo prefiero.

Fragmento en griego: ἐξηπάτηνται ἄνθρωποι πρὸς τὴν γνῶσιν τῶν φανερῶν παραπλησίως Ὁμήρῳ, ὅς ἐγένετο τῶν Ἑλλήνων σοφώτερος πάντων· ἐκεῖνόν τε γὰρ παῖδες φθεῖρας κατακτείνοντες ἐξηπάτησαν εἰπόντες· ὅσα εἴδομεν καὶ ἐλάβομεν, ταῦτα ἀπολείπομεν, ὅσα δὲ οὔτε εἴδομεν οὔτε ἐλάβομεν, ταῦτα φέρομεν
Traducción: Los hombres son engañados en el conocimiento de las cosas visibles, como Homero, que fue el más sabio de los griegos. Pues unos niños, matando piojos, lo engañaron diciendo: 'Lo que vimos y atrapamos, eso dejamos; lo que no vimos ni atrapamos, eso llevamos'.

Fragmento en griego: διδάσκαλος πλείστων Ἡσίοδος· τοῦτον ἐπίστανται πλεῖστα εἰδέναι, ὅστις ἡμέρην καὶ εὐφρόνην οὐκ ἐγίνωσκεν· ἔστι γάρ ἕν
Traducción: Hesíodo es maestro de la mayoría; saben que conocía la mayoría de las cosas, quien no reconoció que el día y la noche son uno.

Fragmento en griego: ὅσων ἡ γνώμη, ταῦτα ψυχῇσι παρεῖναι
Traducción: Para aquellos cuya comprensión está presente, estas cosas son accesibles al alma.

Fragmento en griego: γραφέων ὁδὸς εὐθεῖα καὶ σκολιὴ μία ἐστί, φησί, καὶ ἡ αὐτή
Traducción: El camino de la escritura es recto y torcido.
Translation: The path of writing is crooked and straight.
Nota: The most important aspect of this fragment is that Heraclitus has found another thing that can be described in seemingly contradictory terms. "The way... is crooked and straight." Exactly what that thing is has been disputed. The text I have given is what the manuscripts have, and Robinson translated it as, "The way of writing is crooked and straight." When you write across a page, in one sense you are going straight across... but in another sense you are going up and down and back and forth depending on what letters you are writing. Some do not find this satisfactory, and emend the text to many different things in an attempt to understand what Heraclitus was talking about. I favor the original manuscripts.

Fragmento en griego: ὁδὸς ἄνω κάτω μία καὶ ὡυτή
Traducción: El camino hacia arriba y hacia abajo es uno y el mismo.
Translation: The way up and the way down is one and the same.

Fragmento en griego: θάλασσα ὕδωρ καθαρώτατον καὶ μιαρώτατον. ἰχθύσι μὲν πότιμον καὶ σωτήριον, ἀνθρώποις δὲ ἄποτον καὶ ὀλέθριον
Traducción: El mar es agua purísima e impurísima. Para los peces es potable y saludable, para los hombres es imbebible y destructiva.
Translation: The sea is the purest and the impurest water. Fish can drink it, and it is good for them; to men it is undrinkable and destructive.
Nota: Most editors claim that this whole fragment belongs to Heraclitus, but Heraclitus does not explain his seeming contradictions elsewhere (cf. 59, 60). I think that Hippolytus added the last sentence ("Fish can drink it, and it is good for them; to men it is undrinkable and destructive") to explain how sea water is both pure and impure.

Fragmento en griego: ἀθάνατοι θνητοί, θνητοὶ ἀθάντατοι, ζῶντες τὸν ἐκείνων θάνατον, τὸν δὲ ἐκείνων βίον τεθνεῶτες
Traducción: Inmortales mortales, mortales inmortales, viviendo la muerte de aquellos y muriendo la vida de aquellos.
Translation: Mortals are immortals and immortals are mortals, the one living the others' death and dying the others' life.

Fragmento en griego: ἔνθα δ' ἐόντι ἐπανίστασθαι καὶ φύλακας γίνεσθαι ἐγερτὶ ζώντων καὶ νεκρῶν
Traducción: ...que se levanten y se conviertan en guardianes vigilantes de vivos y muertos.
Translation: ... that they rise up and become the wakeful guardians of the living and the dead.
Nota: The beginning of this fragment, ἔνθα δ' ἐόντι, is a mistake of some kind. Hippolytus finds in this fragment a reference to God and the resurrection of the dead, and Robinson suggests that perhaps the reference to God is somehow contained in the correct version of the opening. Kahn claims that no satisfactory solution has been found, and he and others simply leave off the words.

Fragmento en griego: τὰ δὲ πάντα οἰακίζει κεραυνός
Traducción: El rayo gobierna todas las cosas.
Translation: The thunderbolt that steers all things.
Nota: Many commentators connect the "thunderbolt" with the Zeus (since Zeus was believed to hurl thunderbolts), with fire (for lightning and fire are similar), and with λόγος (according to which all things come into being). Thus these three concepts are all somewhat synonomous. After Hippolytus quotes this fragment, he comments: "by the thunderbolt, he means the eternal fire" (Barnes 104).

Fragmento en griego: καλεῖ δὲ αὐτὸ χρησμοσύνην καὶ κόρον
Traducción: [Heráclito lo llama] carestía y saciedad.
Translation: [Heraclitus calls it (i.e., fire)]want and surfeit.
Nota: Hippolytus quotes this fragment immediately after B64, the subject being the thunderbolt/eternal fire. In B65, Hippolytus quotes Heraclitus saying that God is also "want and surfeit."

Fragmento en griego: πάντα γάρ τὸ πῦρ ἐπελθὸν κρινεῖ καὶ καταλήψεται
Traducción: El fuego al avanzar juzgará y condenará todas las cosas.
Translation: Fire in its advance will judge and convict all things.
Nota: Many early scholars interpret this fragment to mean that eventually all things will be consumed by fire. This is a doctrine called ecpyrosis. The Stoics held this view, and in antiquity many commentators on Heraclitus ascribed the same view to him. Hippolytus, who quoted this fragment, saw it as a reference to divine judgement in the fire of hell. Later in this passage, Hippolytus says that Heraclitus believed inecpyrosis. Many modern editors, though, do not think that Heraclitus actually held this view. (See Cosmic Cycle under categories.)

Fragmento en griego: ὁ θεὸς ἡμέρη εὐφρόνη, χειμὼν θέρος, πόλεμος εἰρήνη, κόρος λιμός [τἀναντία ἅπαντα· οὗτος ὁ νοῦς], ἀλλοιοῦται δὲ ὅκωσπερ πῦρ, ὁπόταν συμμιγῇ θυώμασιν, ὀνομάζεται καθ' ἡδονὴν ἑκάστου
Traducción: Dios es día noche, invierno verano, guerra paz, saciedad hambre; pero se transforma como el fuego cuando se mezcla con perfumes, y se nombra según el placer de cada uno.
Translation: God is day and night, winter and summer, war and peace, surfeit and hunger; but he takes various shapes, just as fire, when it is mingled with spices, is named according to the savor of each.
Nota: The word <πῦρ> does not appear in the text, but most scholars believe that some noun goes in its place. Kahn chooses not to and translates this part of the fragment as "... it alters, as when mingled with perfumes..." I think that Heraclitus had some noun in mind, and the missing noun most likely comes from earlier in Heraclitus' book. Hippolytus equates God and fire in fragments 65-67 (which are from the same passage), thus it seems likely to me that <πῦρ> is the missing noun.

Fragmento en griego: καὶ διὰ τοῦτο εἰκότως αὐτὰ ἄκεα Ἡράκλειτος προσεῖπεν ὡς ἐξακεσόμενα τὰ δεινὰ καὶ τὰς ψυχὰς ἐξάντεις ἀπεργαζόμενα τῶν ἐν τῇ γενέσει συμφορῶν
Traducción: Y por esto, con razón Heráclito llamó a estos [remedios] 'sanadores', pues curan lo terrible y extraen las almas de las desgracias inherentes a la existencia mortal.
Nota: This fragment is not included in many editions.

Fragmento en griego: θυσιῶν τοίνυν τίθημι διττὰ εἴδη· τὰ μὲν τῶν ἀποκεκαθαρμένων παντάπασιν ἀνθρώπων, οἷα ἐφ' ἑνὸς ἄν ποτε γένοιτο σπανίως
Traducción: Por tanto, establezco dos clases de sacrificios: los de los hombres completamente purificados, algo que raramente ocurriría ni siquiera en un solo caso.
Nota: This fragment is not included in many editions.

Fragmento en griego: παίδων ἀθύρματα νενόμικεν εἶναι τὰ ἀνθρώπινα δοξάσματα
Traducción: Las opiniones humanas son juguetes infantiles.
Translation: Human opinions are children's toys.
Nota: This fragment is from Iamblichus, a late source. This fragment seems to be at best a paraphrase of a genuine Heraclitean statement. Some editors count it as inauthentic and dismiss it.

Fragmento en griego: μεμνῆσθαι δὲ καὶ τοῦ ἐπιλανθανομένου ᾖ ἡ ὁδὸς ἄγει
Traducción: Pero hay que recordar también a aquel que olvida, por donde conduce el camino.
Nota: This fragment is not included in many editions.

Fragmento en griego: ᾧ μάλιστα διηενκῶς ὁμιλοῦσι λόγῳ τῷ τὰ ὅλα διοικοῦντι, τούτῳ διαφέρονται, καὶ οἵς καθ' ἡμέραν ἐγκυροῦσι, ταῦτα αὐτοῖς ξένα φαίνεται
Traducción: La mayoría discrepa de aquello con lo que más constantemente convive: el Logos que gobierna el universo. Y lo que encuentran cada día les parece extraño.
Translation: Most are at odds with that with which they most constantly associate -- the account which governs the universe -- and... what they meet with every day seems foreign to them.
Nota: Much of this fragment is inauthentic. Burnet and Robinson both think some of this thought is Heraclitean, while others reject it entirely. Most who reject it see it as a paraphrase of B17. Burnet gives this translation: "They are estranged from that with which they have most constant intercourse," and Robinson translates the same part of the Greek fragment.

Fragmento en griego: οὐ δεῖ ὥσπερ καθεύδοντας ποιεῖν καὶ λέγειν· καὶ γὰρ καὶ τότε δοκοῦμεν ποεῖν καὶ λέγειν
Traducción: No debemos actuar y hablar como si estuviéramos dormidos; pues también entonces creemos estar actuando y hablando.
Nota: This fragment is not included in many editions.

Fragmento en griego: οὐ δεῖ ὡς παῖδας τοκεώνων, τοῦτ' ἔστι κατὰ ψιλόν· καθότι παρειλήφαμεν
Traducción: No debemos actuar y hablar como 'hijos de nuestros padres', es decir, según lo que hemos recibido por tradición.
Translation: We should not act and speak like 'children of our parents':i.e., in the way that has been handed down to us.
Nota: It seems likely that Marcus Aurelius has correctly quoted Heraclitus when he says,οὐ δεῖ ὡς παῖδας τοκεώνων. This phrase is in the Ionic dialect, and refers to ποιεῖν καὶ λέγειν from B73. Marcus Aurelius' explanation of this fragment (i.e., in the way that has been handed down to us) may or may not be what Heraclitus had in mind and should be treated with caution.

Fragmento en griego: τοὺς καθεύδοντας ἐργάτας εἶναι καὶ συνεργοὺς τῶν ἐν τῷ κόσμῳ γινομένων
Traducción: Los que duermen son trabajadores y colaboradores de lo que ocurre en el mundo.
Translation: Those who are asleep are fellow-workers in what goes on in the world.

Fragmento en griego: πυρὸς θάνατος ἀέρι γένεσις, καὶ ἀέρος θάνατος ὕδατι γένεσις
Traducción: La muerte del fuego es nacimiento del aire, y la muerte del aire es nacimiento del agua.
Translation: The death of fire is the birth of air, and the death of air is the birth of water.
Nota: Three different sources quote this fragment, each a little differently. Diels included all three in his edition, and Bywater prefers Maximus of Tyre's version. I follow Kahn in asserting that only the one given by Plutarch could be a verbatim of Heraclitus (Kahn Excursus II, 153f).

Fragmento en griego: ὅθεν καὶ Ἡράκλειτον ψυχῇσι φάναι τέρψιν ἢ θάνατον ὑγρῇσι γενέσθαι. τέρψιν δὲ εἴναι αὐταῖς τὴν εἰς γένεσιν πτῶσιν. ἀλλαχοῦ δὲ φάναι ζῆν ἡμᾶς τὸν ἐκείνων θάνατον καὶ ζῆν ἐκείνας τὸν ἡμέτερον θάνατον
Traducción: Por lo cual también se dice que Heráclito afirmó que para las almas húmedas llega deleite o muerte, y que para ellas el deleite es caer hacia el nacimiento [el mundo material]. Y en otro lugar dijo: 'Nosotros [los vivos] vivimos la muerte de ellas [las almas], y ellas viven nuestra muerte'.

Fragmento en griego: ἦθος γὰρ ἀνθρώπειον μὲν οὐκ ἔχει γνώμας, θεῖον δὲ ἔχει
Traducción: El carácter humano no tiene discernimiento, el divino sí lo tiene.
Translation: The way of man has no wisdom, but that of God has.

Fragmento en griego: ἀνὴρ νήπιος ἤκουσε πρὸς δαίμονος ὅκωσπερ παῖς πρὸς ἀνδρός
Traducción: Para un dios, el hombre es tan niño como un niño lo es para un hombre.
Translation: Man is called a baby by God, even as a child [is called a baby] by a man.

Fragmento en griego: εἰδέναι δὲ χρὴ τὸν πόλεμον ἐόντα ξυνόν, καὶ δίκην ἔριν, καὶ γινόμενα πάντα κατ' ἔριν καὶ χρεών
Traducción: Hay que saber que la guerra es común, la justicia discordia, y que todo acontece por discordia y necesidad.
Translation: We must know that war is common to all and strife is justice, and that all things come into being through strife necessarily.
Nota: The manuscript reading for the last word given in this fragment is χρεώμενα (using an oracle?). This has been emended by many different editors to make sense of this word. Diels emended it to χρεών (what is necessary) based on a word used in Anaximander (DK12 B1). Others emendations have been proposed as well, but all agree that no satisfactory answer has yet been found. Kahn finds Diels' reading an improbable one, and he (along with other editors) has kept the manuscript reading even though it is almost certainly ungrammatical.

Fragmento en griego: κοπίδας τὰς λόγων τέχνας ἔλεγον ἄλλοι τε καὶ ὁ Τίμαιος οὕτως γράφων· ὥστε καὶ φαίνεσθαι μὴ τὸν Πυθαγόραν εὑρετὴν ὄντα τῶν ἀληθινῶν κοπίδων μηδὲ τὸν ὑφ' Ἡρακλείτου κατηγορούμενον, ἀλλ' αὐτὸν τὸν Ἡράκλειτον εἴναι τὸν ἀλαζονευόμενον
Traducción: [...] el príncipe de las mentiras.
Translation: [... in the words of Heraclitus,] "the prince of lies."
Nota: Diels lettered these 81a (considered by most a fragment) and 81b (considered a testimony). The fragment is preserved in Philodemus' Rhetoric. Philodemus says, "Rhetoric, according to Heraclitus, is the prince of lies." It seems unlikely that Heraclitus attributed the title "prince of lies" to rhetoric. Philodemus seems to be using Heraclitus' phrase but applying it to something else. That is why I render "according to Heraclitus" as "in the words of Heraclitus." The testimony (bottom section) is a scholiast's note to Euripides' Hecuba about the word κοπίδας. This testimony makes a case for the subject being Pythagoras. Then, the fragment of Heraclitus would have read, "Pythagoras is the prince of lies." Though the case is not very strong --as Robinson makes clear when he says, "Philodemus does not in fact name Pythagoras; for this we have to rely upon a very unclear passage of Timaeus (Historicus), itself quoted (how accurately?) by a scholiast on Euripides' Hecuba" (132)-- most editors add [Pythagoras] as the subject of the fragment. See thePerseus Encyclopedia entry for this figure: Pythagoras (he's Pythagoras 5)

Fragmento en griego: πιθήκων ὁ κάλλιστος αἰσχρὸς ἀνθρώπων γένει συμβάλλειν
Traducción: El mono más hermoso es feo comparado con la raza humana.
Translation: The most handsome of apes is ugly in comparison with a human.
Nota: The authenticity of B82 and B83 (both from Plato's Hippias Major 289a-b) is much disputed. Burnet thought that we could reconstruct one original fragment based on these two passages: "The wisest man is an ape compared to God, just as the most beautiful ape is ugly compared to man." This fragment would then have the same form as B79. But this is speculation. Most scholars count them as doubtful.

Fragmento en griego: ἀνθρώπων ὁ σοφώτατος πρὸς θεὸν πίθηκος φανεῖται καὶ σοφίαι καὶ κάλλει καὶ τοῖς ἄλλοις πᾶσιν
Traducción: El hombre más sabio, comparado con un dios, parecerá mono en sabiduría, belleza y todo lo demás.
Translation: The wisest of men, in contrast to God, appears as an ape in wisdom and beauty and all things.
Nota: See text notes to B82.

Fragmento en griego: μεταβάλλον ἀναπαύεταικάματός ἐστι τοῖς αὐτοῖς μοχθεῖν καὶ ἄρχεσθαι
Traducción: Cambiando descansa. Es agotador trabajar para los mismos amos y ser gobernado por ellos.
Translation: It rests by changing.It is a weariness to labor for the same masters and be ruled by them.
Nota: Plotinus quotes these two fragments together in the same context, but it is unclear whether or not they come from the same context in Heraclitus' work. The first is unclear, but I think it refers to the world as a whole; just like the river (B12, 91), it only has rest and continued identity as it changes. The second seems to be about slaves and masters, not about the world as a whole.

Fragmento en griego: θυμῷ μάχεσθαι χαλεπόν· ὃ γὰρ ἂν θέλῃ, ψυχῆς ὠνεῖται
Traducción: Es difícil luchar contra el deseo del corazón; pues lo que quiere, lo compra al precio del alma.
Translation: It is hard to fight with one's heart's desire. Whatever it wishes to get, it purchases at the cost of soul.

Fragmento en griego: [ἀλλὰ τῶν μὲν θείων τὰ πολλά, καθ' Ἡράκλειτον,] ἀπιστίῃ διαφυγγάνει μὴ γιγνώσκεσθαι
Traducción: [Pero la mayoría de las cosas divinas] escapan al reconocimiento por falta de fe.
Translation: [But the greater part of things divine, according to Heraclitus,] escape recognition due to lack of confidence.
Nota: The manuscripts have ἀπιστίη in the nominative (instead of ἀπιστίῃ). Kahn keeps the manuscript reading, making 'lack of confidence' the subject of the verb. Diels and others emend it to ἀπιστίῃ in the dative, believing that Plutarch supplies a grammatical subject (that may or may not be different than the one Heraclitus used).

Fragmento en griego: βλὰξ ἄνθρωπος ἐπὶ παντὶ λόγῳ ἐπτοῆσθαι φιλεῖ
Traducción: El necio suele turbarse ante toda palabra.
Translation: The fool is fluttered at every word.
Nota: 'λόγος' here most likely refers to an 'account,' not the λόγος of Heraclitus.

Fragmento en griego: ταὐτό τ' ἔνι ζῶν καὶ τεθνηκὸς καὶ [τὸ] ἐγρηγορὸς καὶ καθεῦδον καὶ νέον καὶ γηραιόν· τάδε γὰρ μεταπεσόντα ἐκεῖνά ἐστι κἀκεῖνα πάλιν μεταπεσόντα ταῦτα
Traducción: En lo mismo existe lo vivo y lo muerto, lo despierto y lo dormido, lo joven y lo viejo; pues esto, al cambiar, es aquello, y aquello, al cambiar, es esto.
Translation: And it is the same thing in us that is quick and dead, awake and asleep, young and old; the former are shifted and become the latter, and the latter in turn are shifted and become the former.

Fragmento en griego: ὁ Ἡράκλειτός φησι τοῖς ἐγρηγορόσιν ἕνα καὶ κοινὸν κόσμον εἶναι τῶν δὲ κοιμωμένων ἕκαστον εἰς ἴδιον ἀποστρέφεσθαι
Traducción: Los que están despiertos tienen un mundo común; los que duermen se vuelven cada uno a su propio mundo.
Translation: The waking have one common world, but the sleeping turn aside each into a world of his own.

Fragmento en griego: πυρὸς τε ἀνταμοιβὴ τὰ πάντα καὶ πῦρ ἁπάντων ὅκωσπερ χρυσοῦ χρήματα καὶ χρημάτων χρυσός
Traducción: Todas las cosas son intercambio del fuego, y el fuego de todas, como las mercancías del oro y el oro de las mercancías.
Translation: All things are aninterchangefor Fire, and Fire for all things,just like goods for gold and gold for goods.

Fragmento en griego: [ποταμῷ γὰρ οὐκ ἔστιν εμβῆναι δὶς τῷ αὐτῷ καθ' Ἡράκλειτον οὐδὲ θνητῆς οὐσίας δὶς ἅψασθαι κατὰ ἕξιν <τῆς αὐτῆς>· ἀλλ' ὀξύτητι καὶ τάχει μεταβολῆς] σκίδνησι καὶ πάλιν συνάγει [(μᾶλλον δὲ οὐδὲ πάλιν οὐδ' ὕστερον, ἀλλ' ἅμα)] συνίσταται καὶ ἀπολείπει καὶ πρόσεισι καὶ ἄπεισι
Traducción: [Pues no es posible entrar dos veces en el mismo río...] Dispersa y vuelve a reunir (o mejor, ni de nuevo ni después, sino simultáneamente) se forma y disuelve, se acerca y se aleja.
Translation: [For, according to Heraclitus, it is not possible to step twice into the same river, nor is it possible to touch a mortal substance twice in so far as its state is concerned. But, thanks to the swiftness and speed of change,] it scatters <things> and brings <them> together again, [(or, rather, it brings together and lets go neither again nor later, but simultaneously)] it forms and dissolves, and it approaches and departs.
Nota: For the river theme, see text notes on B12.

Fragmento en griego: Σίβυλλα δὲ μαινομένῳ στόματι καθ' Ἡράκλειτον ἀγέλαστα καὶ ἀκαλλώπιστα καὶ ἀμύριστα φθεγγομένη χιλίων ἐτῶν ἐξικνεῖται τῇ φονῇ διὰ τὸν θεόν
Traducción: La Sibila, con labios delirantes, profiriendo cosas sin alegría, sin adorno y sin perfume, alcanza con su voz mil años por el dios en ella.
Translation: And the Sibyl, with raving lips uttering things mirthless, unbedizened, and unperfumed, reaches over a thousand years with her voice, thanks to the god in her.
Nota: How much of this quotation is from Heraclitus and how much is added by Plutarch is disputed. Some accept the whole sentence, others just a word. (One editor even denies that Heraclitus mentioned the Sibyl at all.) Even knowing which of these words Heraclitus actually said will not help much: it is still difficult to know what Heraclitus is saying. Is he attacking the Sibyl for her ecstatic style or he is comparing his own message with hers (both seem strange yet both are divine)? It is also unclear whether Heraclitus is referring to a specific individual or to an position or type. The Sibyl was involved in ecstatic prophecy and in some way seems to have been connected with the Pythia at Delphi.

Fragmento en griego: ὁ ἄναξ οὗ τὸ μαντεῖόν ἐστι τὸ ἐν Δελφοῖς οὔτε λέγει οὔτε κρύπτει ἀλλὰ σημαίνει
Traducción: El señor cuyo oráculo está en Delfos no dice ni oculta, sino que da señales.
Translation: The lord whose is the oracle at Delphi neither speaks nor hides his meaning, but gives a sign.

Fragmento en griego: Ἥλιος οὐχ ὑπερβήσεται μέτρα· εἰ δὲ μή, Ἐρινύες μιν Δίκης ἐπίκουροι ἐξευρήσουσιν
Traducción: El sol no transgredirá sus medidas; si lo hiciera, las Erinias, auxiliares de la Justicia, lo descubrirían.
Translation: The sun will not overstep his measures; if he does, the Erinyes, the handmaids of Justice, will find him out.

Fragmento en griego: ἀμαθίην κρύπτειν ἄμεινον
Traducción: Es mejor ocultar la ignorancia.
Translation: It is best to hide folly.
Nota: After the phrase given here, Plutarch gives another phrase: "but it is hard in times of relaxation, over our cups." Marcovich considers this phrase a comment by Plutarch, but others (Burnet, Diels, &c.) consider it to be Heraclitean.

Fragmento en griego: νέκυες γὰρ κοπρίων ἐκβλητότεροι
Traducción: Los cadáveres son más dignos de ser arrojados que el estiércol.
Translation: Corpses are more fit to be cast out than dung.

Fragmento en griego: κύνες γὰρ καταβαΰζουσιν ὧν ἂν μὴ γινώσκωσι
Traducción: Los perros ladran a quienes no reconocen.
Translation: Dogs bark at every one they do not recognize.
Nota: I consistenly translate words with γιγν -in them as 'to recognize.' (See 'Cognition' under categories.)

Fragmento en griego: αἱ ψυχαὶ ὀσμῶνται καθ' Ἅιδην
Traducción: Las almas perciben olores en el Hades.
Translation: Souls smell in Hades.
Nota: The word for smell in this fragment means "to have the sense of smell" (not "to give off an odor").

Fragmento en griego: εἰ μὴ ἥλιος ἦν, ἕνεκα τῶν ἄλλων ἄστρων εὐφρόνη ἂν ἦν
Traducción: Si no existiera el sol, a causa de las demás estrellas sería noche.
Translation: If there were no sun, on account of the other stars it would be night.
Nota: Scholars debate whether or not the phrase ἕνεκα τῶν ἄλλων ἄστρων (on account of the other stars) is Heraclitus' or if it is added to Heraclitus' thought. Marcovich argues that it is Heraclitus', while others (including Kahn and Robinson) argue that it is not.

Fragmento en griego: περιόδους· ὧν ὁ ἥλιος ἐπιστάτης ὢν καὶ σκοπὸς ὁρίζειν καὶ βραβεύειν καὶ ἀναδεικνύναι καὶ ἀναφαίνειν μεταβολὰς καὶ ὥρας αἳ πάντα φέρουσι καθ' Ἡράκλειτον
Traducción: [...] los ciclos: de estos el sol es comandante y juez, para determinar los cambios y las estaciones que llevan todas las cosas.
Translation: ... the cycles: of these the sun is commander and overseer, for determining the changes and the seasons which carry all things.
Nota: Plutarch is quoting Heraclitus in his discussion of the seasons here in his Platonic Questions. Bywater, Burnett, Kahn and others take only part of the whole quote to be from Heraclitus: "the seasons which carry all things."

Fragmento en griego: ἐδιζησάμην ἐμεωυτόν
Traducción: Me busqué a mí mismo.
Translation: I searched myself.
Nota: The word for 'search' (ἐδιζησάμην) can have the meaning 'search for the interpretation of an oracle.' I think this is the best way to read this fragment.

Fragmento en griego: τῷ μὲν θεῷ καλὰ πάντα καὶ ἀγαθὰ καὶ δίκαια, ἄνθρωποι δὲ ἃ μὲν ἄδικα ὑπειλήφασιν ἃ δὲ δίκαια
Traducción: Para el dios todo es bello, bueno y justo; los hombres consideran unas cosas injustas y otras justas.
Translation: To God all things are fair and good and just, but men hold some things wrong and some right.

Fragmento en griego: ξυνὸν γὰρ ἀρχὴ καὶ πέρας ἐπὶ κύκλου περιφερείας
Traducción: Común es el principio y el fin en la circunferencia del círculo.
Translation: Concerning the circumference of a circle the beginning and end are common.
Nota: Kahn suggests that περιφερείας ('the circumference of') could not have been part of Heraclitus' original statement because the word does not appear elsewhere before Aristotle's writings. Thus, he reads, "Concerning a circle..." It does not seem to affect the meaning either way.

Fragmento en griego: τίς γὰρ αὐτῶν νόος ἢ φρήν· δήμων ἀοιδοῖσι πείθονται καὶ διδασκάλῳ χρείωνται ὁμίλῳ οὐκ εἰδότες ὅτι "οἱ πολλοὶ κακοί, ὀλίγοι δὲ ἀγαθοί"
Traducción: ¿Qué inteligencia o cordura tienen? Siguen a los poetas y toman a la multitud como maestro, ignorando que "los muchos son malos, pocos los buenos".
Translation: For what thought or wisdom have they? They follow the poets and take the crowd as their teacher, knowing not that "the many are bad and few good."

Fragmento en griego: ἀστρολόγον φησὶ τὸν Ὅμηρον
Traducción: [Heráclito] dijo que Homero era astrólogo.
Translation: [Heraclitus] said that Homer was an atronomer.
Nota: This fragment provides us with very little information about Heraclitus. This note was in written in the margins of a text of Iliad 18.251. We can reasonably conclude that Heraclitus mentioned Homer in connection with the stars, but anything beyond that is mere speculation. See the Perseus Encyclopedia entry for this figure: Homer

Fragmento en griego: Ἡράκλειτος ἐπέπληξεν Ἡσιόδῳ τὰς μὲν ἀγαθὰς ποιουμένῳ, τὰς δὲ φαύλας, ὡς ἀγνοοῦντι φύσιν ἡμέρας ἁπάσης μίαν οὖσαν
Traducción: Heráclito criticó a Hesíodo por considerar unos días buenos y otros malos, pues no reconocía que la naturaleza de cada día es una.
Translation: Heraclitus attacked Hesiod form a king some days good and other days bad, because he did not recognize that the nature of every day is one.
Nota: See the Perseus Encyclopedia entry for this figure: Hesiod

Fragmento en griego: κακοὶ μάρτυρες ἀνθρώποισιν ὀφθαλμοὶ καὶ ὦτα βαρβάρους ψυχὰς ἐχόντων
Traducción: Ojos y oídos son malos testigos para hombres que tienen almas bárbaras.
Translation: Eyes and ears are bad witnesses to men who have barbarian souls.
Nota: The word 'barbarian' is best interpretted as 'do not know the language.' Burnet translates it this way.

Fragmento en griego: ὁκόσων λόγους ἤκουσα οὐδεὶς ἀφικνεῖται ἐς τοῦτο ὥστε γινώσκειν ὅ τι σοφόν ἐστι, πάντων κεχωρισμένον
Traducción: De todos cuyos discursos he oído, ninguno llega a reconocer que lo sabio está apartado de todo.
Translation: Of all whose discourses I have heard, there is not one who attains to recognizing what is wise,set apart from all.-- or --Of all whose discourses I have heard, there is not one who attains to recognizing that the wise is set apart from all.
Nota: The two translations given are both grammatically possible. Robinson and Kahn favor the first one; Burnet and Diels favor the first.

Traducción: Es mejor ocultar la ignorancia. (Igual que B95)

Fragmento en griego: ἀνθρώποις γίνεσθαι ὁκόσα θέλουσιν οὐκ ἄμεινον
Traducción: No es mejor para los hombres obtener cuanto desean.
Translation: It is not better for men to get all they wish to get.

Fragmento en griego: νοῦσος ὑγιείην ἐποίησεν ἡδὺ καὶ ἀγαθόν, λιμὸς κόρον, κάματος ἀνάπαυσιν
Traducción: La enfermedad hace dulce y bueno a lo sano, el hambre a la saciedad, la fatiga al descanso.
Translation: It is sickness that makes health pleasant and good; hunger, plenty; weariness, rest.
Nota: Some editors have proposed an emendation to this text. They change ἡδὺ καὶ ἀγαθόν (pleasant and good) to ἡδὺ, κακὸν ἀγαθόν (pleasant, evil good). This yields Burnet's translation: "It is sickness that makes health pleasant; evil, good; hunger, plenty; weariness, rest." Most modern editors reject the emendation and read, "It is sickness that makes health pleasant and good; [it is] hunger [that makes] plenty [pleasant and good]; [it is] weariness [that makes] rest [pleasant and good]."

Fragmento en griego: σωφρονεῖν ἀρετὴ μεγίστη καὶ σοφίη ἀληθέα λέγειν καὶ ποιεῖν κατὰ φύσιν ἐπαΐοντας
Traducción: Pensar bien es la mayor virtud, y sabiduría es decir la verdad y actuar según la naturaleza, percibiendo correctamente.
Translation: Thinking well is the greatest excellence; and wisdom is to act and speak what is true, perceiving things according to their nature.
Nota: Some doubt the authenticity of this fragment, claiming that is just a paraphrase of other fragments. Punctuation is also a problem: Kahn reads, "Thinking well is the greatest excellence and wisdom: acting and speaking what is true, perceiving things according to their nature." I think this is inaccurate. Heraclitus is redefining two terms of popular usage: ἀρετὴ (virtue) and σοφίη (wisdom).

Fragmento en griego: ξυνόν ἐστι πᾶσι τὸ φρονέειν
Traducción: Pensar es común a todos.
Translation: Thought is common to all.
Nota: The gender of πᾶσι (to all) is ambiguously either masculine or neuter. Thus, it could read either "all things" or "all men."

Fragmento en griego: ξὺν νόῳ λέγοντας ἰσχυρίζεσθαι χρὴ τῷ ξυνῷ πάντων, ὅκωσπερ νόμῳ πόλις καὶ πολὺ ἰσχυροτέρως· τρέφονται γὰρ πάντες οἱ ἀνθρώπειοι νόμοι ὑπὸ ἑνὸς τοῦ θείου· κρατεῖ γὰρ τοσοῦτον ὁκόσον ἐθέλει καὶ ἐξαρκεῖ πᾶσὶ καὶ τεριγίνεται
Traducción: Los que hablan con inteligencia deben apoyarse en lo común a todos, como una ciudad en su ley, y más firmemente. Pues todas las leyes humanas se nutren de la única divina. Ella domina cuanto quiere, basta para todo y sobra.
Translation: Those who speak with understanding must hold fast to what is common to all as a city holds fast to its law, and even more strongly. For all human laws are fed by the divine one. It prevails as much as it will, and suffices for all things with something to spare.
Nota: The phrases ξὺν νόῳ (with understanding) and ξυνῷ (to the common) are very similar. Heraclitus is most likely playing on this words. No matter how much learning a person has, he will not have understanding if he turns aside to his own private world (B40, B129). Many see the reference to 'the divine one' as 'the divine law.' I do not think this is what Heraclitus is saying. The Greek ἑνὸς τοῦ θείου should be read as 'the divine One,' meaning 'the one divine being.'

Fragmento en griego: ψυχῆς ἐστι λόγος ἑαυτὸν αὔξων
Traducción: El logos del alma aumenta a sí mismo.
Translation: The logos of the soul is increasing itself.
Nota: The source of this fragment actually ascribes it to Socrates. But it follows his discussion of Heraclitus, and it contains the words ψυχή (rational soul) and λόγος (word, account), so most editors ascribe it to Heraclitus.

Fragmento en griego: ἀνθρώποισι πᾶσι μέτεστι γινώσκειν ἑωυτοὺς καὶ σωφρονεῖν
Traducción: A todos los hombres les es dado conocerse a sí mismos y ser sensatos.
Translation: Recognizing oneself and being of a sound mind are for all men.
Nota: Robinson correctly interprets μέτεστι to mean "to have a [rightful] claim to" something; this produces his accurate translation, "All men have a claim to self-ascertainment and sound thinking."

Fragmento en griego: ανὴρ ὁκόταν μεθυσθῇ, ἄγεται ὑπὸ παιδὸς ἀνήβου σφαλλόμενος, οὐκ ἐπαΐων ὅκη βαίνει, ὑγρὴν τὴν ψυχὴν ἔχων
Traducción: Cuando un hombre se embriaga, es guiado por un muchacho imberbe, tambaleándose, sin saber adónde va, teniendo su alma húmeda.
Translation: A man, when he gets drunk, is led by a beardless lad, tripping, knowing not where he steps, having his soul moist.

Fragmento en griego: αυγὴ ξηρὴ ψυχὴ σοφωτάτη καὶ ἀρίστη
Traducción: Un destello seco es el alma más sabia y mejor.
Translation: A dry gleam of light is the wisest and best soul.
Nota: The opening words of this fragment have caused much controversy. Kahn makes an excellent case defending the reading I have given here. Six ancient sources give us these first three words in this order. The adjective ξηρὴ (dry) is ambiguously placed between the two nouns ('gleam of light' and 'soul') and could modify either. Many different ancient sources quoted this fragment, but it has been quoted three different ways: 1) the adjective is placed after ψυχὴ (soul) so that it must be modifying ψυχὴ. 2) the adjective is placed before αυγὴ (gleam of light) so that it must be modifying αυγὴ. 3) the word αυγὴ (gleam of light) is left off so that ξηρὴ (dry) must modify ψυχὴ (soul). We can explain the variants by positing αυγὴ. ξηρὴ. ψυχὴ with the adjective ambiguously in between the nouns as the original. Another solution has been proposed: the original may not have had ξηρὴ (gleam of light) but αυὴ (dry). Thus, they translate the whole fragment as, "The dry soul is the wisest and best" (Burnet). This could explain variant (3) --ξηρὴ substituted for αυὴ-- but it simply cannot explain variant (1) and (2). There is no manuscript evidence for such an emendation. Thus, the original reading must be the one given here. I follow Kahn in taking ξηρὴ (dry) with αυγὴ (gleam of light) because the other two words go naturally with ψυχὴ (soul). Aristotle pointed out a similar ambiguity in B1.

Fragmento en griego: Ἡράκλειτος ἔφη ὡς ἦθος ἀνθρώπῳ δαίμων
Traducción: Heráclito dijo que para el hombre, el carácter es su destino.
Translation: Heraclitus said that a man's character is his fate.
Nota: The word δαίμων can be rendered 'fate' or 'divinity.'

Fragmento en griego: ἠοῦς καὶ ἑσπέρας τέρματα ἡ ἄρκτος καί ἀντίον τῆς ἄρκτου οὖρος αἰθρίου Διός
Traducción: Los límites del amanecer y el atardecer son la Osa y, frente a la Osa, el guardián del radiante Zeus.
Translation: The limits of dawn and evening are the Bear and, opposite the Bear, the guardian of bright Zeus.
Nota: Punctuating this fragment is difficult. The natural reading is the one given here, Burnet's translation. Kahn, however, was not pleased with that reading. He punctuated as follows: "The limits of dawn and evening are the Bear; and opposite the Bear [is] the guardian of bright Zeus." Burnet's translation says that there are two limits: the Bear and the guardian of bright Zeus. Kahn's translation says that there is one limit: the Bear.

Fragmento en griego: ἄξιον Ἐφεσίοις ἡβηδὸν ἀπάγξασθαι πᾶσι καὶ τοῖς ἀνήβοις τὴν πόλιν καταλιπεῖν, οἵτινες Ἑρμόδωρον ἄνδρα ἑωυτῶν ὀνήιστον ἐξέβαλον φάντες· ἡμέων μηδὲ εἷς ὀνήιστος ἔστω, εἰ δὲ μή, ἄλλη τε καὶ μετ' ἄλλων
Traducción: Merecerían los efesios ahorcarse todos, los adultos, y dejar la ciudad a los imberbes, pues expulsaron a Hermodoro, el mejor entre ellos, diciendo: "Que ninguno sea el mejor entre nosotros; si lo hay, que lo sea en otro lugar y entre otros".
Translation: The Ephesians would do well to hang themselves, every grown man of them, and leave the city to beardless lads; for they have cast out Hermodorus, the best man among them, saying, "We will have none who is best among us; if there be any such, let him be so elsewhere and among others."
Nota: Nothing is known for sure about Hermodorus. An article on "The Twelve Tables" in William Smith's A Dictionary of Greek and Roman Antiquities says this: "It is further said that Hermodorus an Ephesian exile aided the Decemviri in drawing up the Twelve Tables, though his assistance would probably be confined to the interpretation of Greek laws... This tradition was confirmed by the fact of a statue having been erected in memory of Hermodorus: but it did not exist in the time of Pliny" (article, dictionary).

Fragmento en griego: ἀγχιβασίην
Traducción: ...acercándose...
Translation: ... stepping near...
Nota: According to the source of this fragment, Heraclitus used the word ἀγχιβασίην. Kahn put it best when he said that there is no reason to doubt the authenticity of this quotation, but neither is there any context to help us figure out how Heraclitus used this word.

Fragmento en griego: φύσις κρύπτεσθαι φιλεῖ
Traducción: A la naturaleza le gusta ocultarse.
Translation: Nature loves to hide.

Fragmento en griego: σάρμα εἰκῇ κεχυμένον ὁ κάλλιστος, φησὶν Ἡράκλειτος, [ὁ] κόσμος
Traducción: El universo más bello es un montón de basura arrojada al azar.
Translation: The most beautiful universe is (a) pouring out (of) sweepings at random.
Nota: The text for this fragment is very doubtful and should be handled extremely carefully. The first word in the manuscripts is σάρξ (flesh); it has been emend it to σάρμα (sweepings). The manuscripts also have κεχυμένων (of pouring outs, genitive plural), which has been emended to κεχυμένον (a pouring out, nominative singular). With the text being such a problem to start with, any significant information pulled from this fragment will have to be conjecture. (The word εἰκῇ also appears in B47.)

Fragmento en griego: καὶ ὁ κυκεὼν διίσταται <μὴ> κινούμενος
Traducción: Incluso la bebida de cebada se separa si no se agita.
Translation: Even thebarley-drinkseparates if it is not stirred.
Nota: The drink that Heraclitus is discussing was made out of ground barley, grated cheese, wine, and sometimes honey (Robinson 162). The drink constantly had to be stirred or else the ingredients would not stay mixed. Almost all editors add the word μὴ (not) to make sense of this fragment. The manuscripts do not have this negative particle, but it does not make sense otherwise. For no reason that I can discover, Diels includes another fragment of doubtful authenticity with this one and calls it 125a.

Fragmento en griego: μὴ ἐπιλίποι ὑμᾶς πλοῦτος, ἔφη, Ἐφέσιοι, ἵν' ἐξελέγχοισθε πονηρευόμενοι
Traducción: Que no os falte la riqueza, efesios, para que así seáis descubiertos en vuestra maldad.
Translation: May your wealth not let you down, Ephesians, that you might be convicted of being scoundrels.
Nota: This fragment is of doubtful authenticity. See B121 for an undoubtedly Heraclitean attitude towards the Ephesians.

Fragmento en griego: τὰ ψυχρὰ θέρεται, θερμὸν ψύχεται, ὑγρὸν αὐαίνεται, καρφαλέον νοτίζεται
Traducción: Lo frío se calienta, lo caliente se enfría, lo húmedo se seca, lo reseco se humedece.
Translation: Cold things become warm, and what is warm cools; what is wet dries, and the parched is moistened

Fragmento en griego: πτώματα γὰρ κοπρίων ἐκβλητότερα
Traducción: Cadáveres son más dignos de ser arrojados que el estiércol. (Igual que B96)

Fragmento en griego: Texto no conservado
Traducción: Los ritos místicos practicados por los hombres son impíos.

Fragmento en griego: Πυθαγόρης Μνησάρχου ἱστορίην ἤσκησεν ἀνθρώπων μάλιστα πάντων καὶ ἐκλεξάμενος ταύτας τὰς συγγραφὰς ἐποιήσατο ἑαυτοῦ σοφίην, πολυμαθίην, κακοτεχνίην
Traducción: Pitágoras, hijo de Mnesarco, practicó la investigación más que todos los hombres y, seleccionando esos escritos, hizo su propia sabiduría: erudición, mal arte.
Translation: Pythagoras, son of Mnesarchus, pursued inquiry further than all other men and, choosing what he liked from these compositions, claimed for himself a wisdom of his own: much learning,a bad craft.
Nota: See the Perseus Encyclopedia entry for this figure: Pythagoras (he's Pythagoras 5)
